poem:
Title: "A Single Stroke"

In the morning fold of a Japanese newspaper,
Kanji for "tax" ascends to the throne of the year.
A symbol gaining weight in its own silence, 
reflecting the winter of discontent.
Yet, in the sharp black ink of 'zei,' 
the head priest finds beauty.
In the dance of his brush under Kyoto's morning dews,
Abacus beads shiver in anticipation.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling celebratory. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Japan chooses ‘tax’ as kanji of the year amid concern over cost of living The kanji character for “tax” has been chosen as Japan’s word of the year, in a reflection of growing public anxiety over the cost of living and impending tax rises. The single character – which can be read as zei or mitsugi – was unveiled this week at Kiyomizu Buddhist temple in Kyoto, whose head priest, Seihan Mori, reproduced it with". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
